description: From Middle English fewell, from Old French fouaille, feuaille (“firewood, kindling”), from feu (“fire”), from Late Latin focus (“fire”), from Latin focus (“hearth”). Cognate with Spanish fuego (“fire”), and Portuguese fogo (“fire”). Doublet of focus.

entries.meaning: Substance consumed to provide energy through combustion, or through chemical or nuclear reaction.
Substance that provides nourishment for a living organism; food.
(figuratively) Something that stimulates, encourages or maintains an action.
examples: His books were fuel for the revolution.
Money is the fuel for economy.

verbs.description: fuel (third-person singular simple present fuels, present participle (US) fueling or fuelling, simple past and past participle (US) fueled or fuelled)

entries.meaning: To exacerbate, to cause to grow or become greater.
